signiﬁcant increase of concentration above the level needed for
phase stabilization leads to a substitution in the Zr octahedral
sites which might lead to phase decomposition and, therefore, a
decrease in Li-ion conductivity. Substitution on the

Ga has been also used as a substituting element on the

reported, due to a large grain boundary resistance.
shown to improve the total Li-ion conductivity to 1 mS cm

Simultaneous substitutions have also been reported in the
although conductivities remain at the levels
It has been shown that the improvement of the density of
garnet materials leads to an improvement in the total Li-ion
conductivity. It seems rather diﬃcult to stabilize the cubic phase
and to obtain high density materials without any undesired
impurities or the presence of the undesirable tetragonal phase.
Expensive methods such as hot-press or spark plasma sintering
lead to stable cubic phases and values close to 90% theoretical
density although they are still far from the 98
However, it seems possible to obtain
very high densities for the tetragonal La
means of the use of a hot-press as it has recently been shown by
In a recent study, El Shinawi
reported a slightly diﬀerent strategy; using Ga as a sintering aid
rather than a substituent, obtaining densities close to 92%. In
this work, they did not ﬁnd any clear evidence of the insertion
of Ga in the garnet structure, but this strategy led them to
stabilize the cubic phase and to obtain total Li-ion
conductivities as high as 0.5 mS cm
in the increase of density have been shown by Li et al.
using lithium oxide as additive in a Ta-substituted garnet. In
this case, an increase of the relative density from 91.5% to
97.3% was shown that led them to conductivities of 0.64 mS
Furthermore, all these problems (i.e., processing of high
density samples, high grain boundary resistance, etc.) in
seem to be related with its reactivity with
atmospheric moisture. A recent study by Larraz et al.
shown the diﬀerent structural changes that this material can
undergo when it is in contact with diﬀerent levels of
atmospheric moisture. The authors of this report claim that
these changes are probably due to the high reactivity of the Li
from the water or the introduction of water
molecules into the structure, which would lead to a large Li-ion
conductivity decrease. A very recent report by Li et al.
the improvement in the total Li-ion conductivity of an
sintering was done under pure O
taken to avoid contact with moisture.
Therefore, in this work we have taken into account all the
issues related to the stabilization of the cubic phase with high Li
content and to the control of densiﬁcation and contact with
moisture to produce high Li-ion conducting materials. First, we
aim to substitute Li by small amounts of Ga in the
material in order to promote the creation
shows the crystal structure of the La
where the Li path created by extra vacancy generation is shown
in Figure 1b. Second, we aim to optimize the sintering
conditions with minimal moisture contact for our samples, in
as sintering gas. Following this scheme
we have synthesized a series of Ga-substituted La
materials with the general formula La
studied in detail the eﬀects of atmospheric moisture during

Sigma-Aldrich)). These materials were mixed in stoichiometric
quantities (+10% Li excess) and consequently dissolved in a citric
acid solution with some drops of HNO
. The resulting gel was ﬁred at
C for 12 h in air to burn oﬀ the organic components. After this
treatment, the powder was ground and reheated to 800
